title: Episode 2-1 Highlights | Kim Soo-hyun Secretly Dreams of Escaping His In-Laws' House...!?
synopsis: Hong Hye-in receives a devastating diagnosis—a rare brain tumor with only three months to live. As Hyun-woo processes the news, his friend suggests he use this as an opportunity. But on their wedding anniversary, Hyun-woo shows up with flowers, choosing a different path.

subtitles.original: 지난번에도 말씀드렸잖아요 가끔 두통 있었고 깜빡깜빡 했었고 가끔은.
subtitles.pronunciation: Jinanbeon-edo malsseum-deuryeotjanayo gakkeum dutong isseotgo kkamppak-kkamppak haesseotgo gakkeum-eun.
subtitles.translation: I told you last time too—I had occasional headaches and kept forgetting things sometimes.

grammar.explanation: Ending indicating shared knowledge or reminder

subtitles.original: 상반기 VIP고객 대상 아트클래스 반응이 좋았어요. 유명작가들 초대전.
subtitles.pronunciation: Sangbangi VIP-gogaek daesang ateu-keullaseu baneung-i joasseoyo. Yumyeong-jakga-deul chodaejeon.
subtitles.translation: The first-half art class for VIP customers got good response. The famous artists' exhibition.

grammar.explanation: Noun meaning 'first half of the year'

subtitles.culture: Department stores in Korea offer exclusive events like art classes for VIP customers as part of their premium services.

subtitles.original: 에스테아 입점하잖아요. 요즘 수면제 때.
subtitles.pronunciation: Eseutea ipjeom-hajanayo. Yojeum sumyeonje ttae.
subtitles.translation: Estea is opening a store. These days with sleeping pills...

grammar.explanation: Verb meaning 'to open a store/enter a market'

subtitles.original: 10분 아니 30분 어떨 땐 몇 시간 내가 뭘 했는지 기억이 안 난 적도 있었어요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Sipbun ani samsipbun eotteo ttaen myeot sigan naega mwol haenneunjji gieok-i an nan jeokdo isseosseoyo.
subtitles.translation: 10 minutes, no 30 minutes, sometimes even hours—there were times I couldn't remember what I did.

grammar.example: 기억이 안 난 적도 = times when I couldn't remember

subtitles.original: 사장님 아까 일정 다 취소하고 백현우 사장님 만나러 가신다더니 아직 안 가셨어요?
subtitles.pronunciation: Sajangnim akka iljeong da chwiso-hago Baek Hyeonu sajangnim mannareо gasindadeoni ajik an gasyeosseoyo?
subtitles.translation: Director, you said you cancelled all your schedule to meet Director Baek Hyun-woo. Haven't you left yet?

grammar.example: 가신다더니 = you said you were going, but

subtitles.original: 그래서 중요한 약속을 놓치기도 했고요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Geuraeseo jungyohan yaksok-eul nochigi-do haetgoyo.
subtitles.translation: So I've missed important appointments too.

grammar.example: 약속을 놓치다 = to miss an appointment

subtitles.original: 네.
subtitles.pronunciation: Ne.
subtitles.translation: Yes.

subtitles.original: 그런데 왜 병원에 이제 오셨죠?
subtitles.pronunciation: Geureonde wae byeongwon-e ije osyeotjyo?
subtitles.translation: But why did you only come to the hospital now?

grammar.example: 이제 오셨죠 = you came only now

subtitles.original: 너무 피곤해서 잠깐 졸았나.
subtitles.pronunciation: Neomu pigonhaeseo jamkkan jorassna.
subtitles.translation: I thought maybe I dozed off because I was too tired.

subtitles.original: 아님 멍해졌나 싶었고 특별히 통증이 있거나 어디가 아프진 않았으니까.
subtitles.pronunciation: Anim meonghaejyeotna sipeotgo teukbyeolhi tongjeung-i itgeona eodiga apeujin anasseuni-kka.
subtitles.translation: Or maybe I just spaced out. There wasn't any particular pain or anything hurting.

grammar.example: 멍해졌나 싶었고 = thought maybe I spaced out
졸았나 싶었고 = thought maybe I dozed off

subtitles.original: 그런데 뭐가 안 좋은가요?
subtitles.pronunciation: Geureonde mwoga an joeungayo?
subtitles.translation: So, is something wrong?

grammar.example: 뭐가 안 좋은가요 = is something wrong?

subtitles.original: 글리오마 세포종인데 정말 보기 드문 케이스입니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Geulioma sepojong-inde jeongmal bogi deumeun keiseu-imnida.
subtitles.translation: It's a glioma cell tumor—a very rare case.

grammar.example: 보기 드문 케이스 = a rare case

subtitles.culture: Glioma is a type of brain tumor. The drama uses a fictional rare variant to create dramatic tension.

subtitles.original: 전 세계적으로도 몇 안 되고 우리나라에선 거의 첫 케이스나 마찬가지라고 보면 되고요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Jeon segyejeogeuro-do myeot an doego uri-nara-eseon geoeui cheot keiseu-na machangaji-rago bomyeon doegoyo.
subtitles.translation: There are only a few cases worldwide, and in Korea, you could say this is practically the first case.

grammar.example: 몇 안 되고 = there are only a few
첫 케이스나 마찬가지 = practically the first case

subtitles.original: 수술해야 되나요?
subtitles.pronunciation: Susul-haeya doenayo?
subtitles.translation: Do I need surgery?

grammar.example: 수술해야 되나요 = do I have to have surgery?

subtitles.original: 아니요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Aniyo.
subtitles.translation: No.

subtitles.original: 약물만으로 가능하군요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Yangmul-maneuro ganeung-hagunyo.
subtitles.translation: So it's treatable with just medication.

subtitles.original: 이런 케이스가 더 어려운 게 일반 종양하고는 형태부터가 다릅니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Ireon keiseu-ga deo eoryeoun ge ilban jongyang-hagoneun hyeongtae-buteoga dareumnida.
subtitles.translation: This type of case is more difficult because its form is different from regular tumors.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'different from the start/fundamentally different'
grammar.example: 형태부터가 다릅니다 = the form itself is different

subtitles.original: 명백한 종양덩어리로 자리 잡고 있는 게 아니고 뇌신경들 사이에 종양세포가 이렇게 안개처럼 퍼져있습니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Myeongbaekhan jongyang-deongeori-ro jari japgo inneun ge anigo noesingyeong-deul sai-e jongyang-sepo-ga ireoke angae-cheoreom peojyeo-itsseumnida.
subtitles.translation: It's not sitting as a clear tumor mass—the tumor cells are spread like fog between the brain nerves.

grammar.example: 자리 잡고 있는 게 아니고 = it's not sitting in one place

subtitles.original: 심지어 굉장히 광범위합니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Simjieo goengjanghi gwangbeomwi-hamnida.
subtitles.translation: Moreover, it's extremely widespread.

subtitles.original: 특히 이 측두엽 쪽이 심한데
subtitles.pronunciation: Teukhi i cheukduyeop jjok-i simhande
subtitles.translation: The temporal lobe area is especially severe.
subtitles.culture: The temporal lobe is responsible for memory, hearing, and emotional processing—explaining Hye-in's memory loss symptoms.

subtitles.original: 그래서 순간적인 기억소실 증상 등이 나타났던 것 같고요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Geuraeseo sunganjeok-in gieok-sosil jeungsang deung-i natanatteon geot gatgoyo.
subtitles.translation: That's why symptoms like momentary memory loss appeared.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'it seems that (in the past)'
grammar.example: 나타났던 것 같고요 = it seems it appeared

subtitles.original: 흔치 않은 병이고 증상도 케이스마다 케이스로 다양하고 비특이적인데
subtitles.pronunciation: Heunchi aneun byeong-igo jeungsang-do keiseu-mada keiseu-ro dayangago biteuk-ijeogin-de
subtitles.translation: It's a rare disease, and symptoms vary from case to case and are non-specific.

grammar.example: 흔치 않은 병 = a rare disease

subtitles.original: 심해지면 환각이나 성격장애 등이 올 수 있습니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Simhaejimyeon hwangak-ina seonggyeok-jangae deung-i ol su itsseumnida.
subtitles.translation: If it worsens, hallucinations or personality disorders can occur.

subtitles.original: 문제는 약물 치료도 의미가 별로 없고 수술은 아예 불가능합니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Munje-neun yangmul chiryo-do uimi-ga byeollo eopgo susul-eun aye bulganeung-hamnida.
subtitles.translation: The problem is medication has little effect, and surgery is completely impossible.

grammar.example: 의미가 별로 없고 = has little meaning

subtitles.original: 종양처럼 어느 한 부분만 떼어낼 수 있는 게 아니라서요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Jongyang-cheoreom eoneu han bubun-man tteeonal su inneun ge aniraseоyo.
subtitles.translation: Unlike a tumor, we can't just remove one part.

grammar.example: 떼어낼 수 있는 게 아니라서 = because we can't remove

subtitles.original: 홍혜인 씨. 홍혜인 씨.
subtitles.pronunciation: Hong Hyein ssi. Hong Hyein ssi.
subtitles.translation: Ms. Hong Hye-in. Ms. Hong Hye-in.

grammar.explanation: Polite title suffix used with names

subtitles.original: 괜찮으세요?
subtitles.pronunciation: Gwaenchaneusеyo?
subtitles.translation: Are you okay?

subtitles.original: 알겠어요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Algesseoyo.
subtitles.translation: I understand.

subtitles.original: 네?
subtitles.pronunciation: Ne?
subtitles.translation: Pardon?

grammar.explanation: Expression of surprise or asking to repeat

subtitles.original: 보통 사람들한텐 그렇다는 거잖아요. 잘 알겠다고요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Botong saram-deul-hanten geureotdaneun geojanayo. Jal algetdagoyo.
subtitles.translation: That's for ordinary people. I said I understand.
subtitles.culture: Hye-in's response shows her chaebol mindset—believing rules for 'ordinary people' don't apply to her due to her wealth and power.

subtitles.original: 이젠 내가 받을 수 있는 치료에 대해서 얘기해 주세요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Ijen naega badeul su inneun chiryo-e daehaeseo yaegi-hae juseyo.
subtitles.translation: Now tell me about the treatment I can receive.

subtitles.original: 일반 케이스 말고 나요 내 케이스요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Ilban keiseu malgo nayo nae keiseu-yo.
subtitles.translation: Not the general case—me, my case.

grammar.example: 일반 케이스 말고 = not the general case

subtitles.original: 소아병원 건립기금은 마련하고 있다고 들었는데 내가 해결할 수 있어요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Soa-byeongwon geollip-gigeum-eun maryeon-hago itdago deureotneunde naega haegyeol-hal su isseoyo.
subtitles.translation: I heard you're raising funds for a children's hospital. I can take care of that.
subtitles.culture: Hye-in attempts to use her wealth to get special treatment—a common trope showing how chaebols try to buy their way out of problems.

subtitles.original: 어떻게 하면 저거 다 없앨 수 있는지 말해 주세요.
subtitles.pronunciation: Eotteoke hamyeon jeogeo da eopael su inneunji malhae juseyo.
subtitles.translation: Tell me how I can get rid of all that.

grammar.example: 없앨 수 있는지 = whether I can eliminate

subtitles.original: 제가 아는 한 아직까지 증명된 의학적인 방법은 없습니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Jega aneun han ajikkkaji jeungmyeongdoen uihakjeok-in bangbeop-eun eopseumnida.
subtitles.translation: As far as I know, there's no proven medical method yet.

grammar.example: 제가 아는 한 = as far as I know

subtitles.original: 두통이나 순간적인 기억소실 등의 증상을 완화시킬 수 있는 약을 쓰는 게 최선입니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Dutong-ina sunganjeok-in gieok-sosil deung-ui jeungsang-eul wanhwa-sikil su inneun yak-eul sseuneun ge choeseon-imnida.
subtitles.translation: Using medication that can alleviate symptoms like headaches and momentary memory loss is the best we can do.

grammar.example: 완화시킬 수 있는 = that can alleviate

subtitles.original: 하지만 원천적인 병의 치료는 지금으로서는 불가능합니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Hajiman woncheonjeok-in byeong-ui chiryo-neun jigeumeuroseo-neun bulganeung-hamnida.
subtitles.translation: But fundamentally curing the disease is impossible at this point.

subtitles.original: 아까부터 교수님은 내가 곧 죽는다는 말을 하고 싶은가 본데
subtitles.pronunciation: Akkabuteo gyosunim-eun naega got jungneundaneun mar-eul hago sipeun-ga bonde
subtitles.translation: Since earlier, it seems you've been wanting to tell me I'm going to die soon.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'it seems you want to'
grammar.example: 하고 싶은가 본데 = seems like you want to say

subtitles.original: 그래요. 들어나 보죠. 내가 언제 죽는다는 건데요?
subtitles.pronunciation: Geuraeyo. Deureona bojyo. Naega eonje jungneundaneun geondeyо?
subtitles.translation: Fine. Let's hear it. When am I going to die?
subtitles.culture: Hye-in's direct, almost confrontational way of asking about her death reflects her strong, no-nonsense personality.

subtitles.original: 종양세포가 퍼진 상태로 봤을 땐 석 달 정도 생각합니다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Jongyang-sepo-ga peojin sangtae-ro bwasseul ttaen seok dal jeongdo saenggak-hamnida.
subtitles.translation: Based on how the tumor cells have spread, I estimate about three months.

grammar.example: 상태로 봤을 땐 = based on the condition

subtitles.original: 콧노래라니 돌았니? 진짜 순장당하고 싶어?
subtitles.pronunciation: Konnorae-rani doranni? Jinjja sunjang-danghago sipeo?
subtitles.translation: Humming? Are you crazy? Do you want to be buried alive with her?

grammar.explanation: Historical term for being buried alive with the deceased
grammar.example: 순장당하고 싶어 = want to be buried alive?

subtitles.culture: 순장 was an ancient practice of burying servants alive with their masters. Used here sarcastically to warn about the dangers of going against the chaebol family.

subtitles.original: 슬프다. 사별이라니.
subtitles.pronunciation: Seulpeuda. Sabyeol-irani.
subtitles.translation: How sad. Death of a spouse.

grammar.example: 사별이라니 = death of a spouse, of all things

subtitles.original: 이혼하지 않아도 석 달만 버티면 사별이라니.
subtitles.pronunciation: Ihon-haji anado seok dal-man beotimyeon sabyeol-irani.
subtitles.translation: If I just hold on for three months without divorcing, it becomes widowhood.

grammar.example: 석 달만 버티면 = if I just hold on for 3 months

subtitles.culture: This dark humor reveals Hyun-woo's conflicted feelings—part of him realizes that waiting out her death would 'solve' his problems without the stigma of divorce.

subtitles.original: 안 돼.
subtitles.pronunciation: An dwae.
subtitles.translation: No. I can't.

subtitles.original: 내려가. 잉꼬리. 내려가.
subtitles.pronunciation: Naeryeoga. Ingkkori. Naeryeoga.
subtitles.translation: Get off. Lovebird. Get off.
subtitles.culture: 잉꼬 (lovebird) is used sarcastically here, mocking Hyun-woo's sudden change of heart.

subtitles.original: 홍혜인?
subtitles.pronunciation: Hong Hyein?
subtitles.translation: Hong Hye-in?

grammar.explanation: Using someone's name as a question expresses surprise

subtitles.original: 아니 시계보다 더 정확한 사람이 무슨 일이야?
subtitles.pronunciation: Ani sigyeboda deo jeonghwakhan saram-i museun iriya?
subtitles.translation: Wait, someone more punctual than a clock—what's going on?

grammar.example: 시계보다 더 정확한 = more accurate than a clock

subtitles.original: 저기. 지금 일곱 시 넘었어.
subtitles.pronunciation: Jeogi. Jigeum ilgop si neomeosseo.
subtitles.translation: Um. It's past 7 o'clock now.
subtitles.culture: Hye-in is always extremely punctual. Being late indicates something is seriously wrong.

subtitles.original: 아이고.
subtitles.pronunciation: Aigo.
subtitles.translation: Oh my.

grammar.explanation: Common exclamation of surprise or sympathy

subtitles.original: 왜? 뭐?
subtitles.pronunciation: Wae? Mwo?
subtitles.translation: Why? What?

subtitles.original: 오늘 당신은 기분이 굿인가 봐 굿모닝이고.
subtitles.pronunciation: Oneul dangsin-eun gibun-i gut-inga bwa gutmoning-igo.
subtitles.translation: You seem to be in a good mood today. Good morning.

grammar.example: 굿인가 봐 = seems like it's good

subtitles.culture: Hye-in uses English loanwords like 'good' and 'good morning' casually, reflecting the Westernized speech patterns common among wealthy Koreans.

subtitles.original: 피부도 유난히 좋아 보이네. 꿀잠 잤나 봐.
subtitles.pronunciation: Pibu-do yunanhi joa boine. Kkuljam janna bwa.
subtitles.translation: Your skin looks especially good. You must have slept well.

grammar.example: 유난히 좋아 보이네 = looks especially good
꿀잠 잤나 봐 = seems like you slept well

subtitles.culture: 꿀잠 (honey sleep) is modern Korean slang for a really good, deep sleep. 꿀 (honey) is used as a prefix for anything excellent.

subtitles.original: 난 뜬눈으로 밤새 뒤척였는데.
subtitles.pronunciation: Nan tteunnun-euro bamsae dwicheok-yeotneunde.
subtitles.translation: Meanwhile, I tossed and turned all night with my eyes open.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'with eyes open/unable to sleep'
grammar.example: 뜬눈으로 밤새 = all night with eyes open

subtitles.original: 내가? 내 피부가? 아닌데. 아닌데 그럴 리가 없는데.
subtitles.pronunciation: Naega? Nae pibu-ga? Aninde. Aninde geureol riga eomneunde.
subtitles.translation: Me? My skin? No way. No way, that can't be.

grammar.example: 그럴 리가 없는데 = that can't be

subtitles.culture: Hyun-woo is shocked that he could look good after learning his wife has three months to live—indicating his guilt over his conflicted feelings.

subtitles.original: 아니 백현우 우리 전공에 맞게 대화를 좀 해보죠.
subtitles.pronunciation: Ani Baek Hyeonu uri jeongong-e matge daehwa-reul jom haebojyo.
subtitles.translation: Hey Baek Hyun-woo, let's have a conversation befitting our profession.

subtitles.original: 윤원장 석 달이면 열 번도 고백할 수 있는 거 알잖아.
subtitles.pronunciation: Yun-wonjang seok dal-imyeon yeol beon-do gobaek-hal su inneun geo aljanah.
subtitles.translation: Director Yoon, you know in three months you could confess your love ten times over.

subtitles.original: 그러니까 넌 이제부터 석 달 안에 니 와이프가 이 남자가 날 이렇게 사랑하다니.
subtitles.pronunciation: Geureonikka neon ijebuteo seok dal ane ni waipeu-ga i namja-ga nal ireoke sarang-hadani.
subtitles.translation: So from now on, within three months, make your wife think 'This man loves me this much.'

grammar.example: 사랑하다니 = to think he loves me this much

subtitles.original: 내 분신인 퀸즈 백화점을 통째로 안겨주고 가야겠다.
subtitles.pronunciation: Nae bunsin-in Kwinsjeu baekhwajeom-eul tongjaero angyeojugo gayagetda.
subtitles.translation: 'I should give him Queens Department Store, my alter ego, entirely before I go.'

grammar.example: 내 분신인 = which is my alter ego
안겨주고 가야겠다 = should give before going

subtitles.culture: Queens Department Store is Hye-in's life work and the symbol of her identity. The friend suggests manipulating her into leaving it to Hyun-woo.

subtitles.original: 이런 생각이 딱 들도록 만들면 되는 거고.
subtitles.pronunciation: Ireon saenggak-i ttak deuldorok mandeulmyeon doeneun geogo.
subtitles.translation: You just need to make her think exactly that.

grammar.example: 들도록 만들면 = if you make her think

subtitles.original: 뭔 소리야?
subtitles.pronunciation: Mwon soriya?
subtitles.translation: What are you talking about?

grammar.example: 뭔 소리야 = what are you saying?

subtitles.original: 겨우 석 달이야. 너 군대 2년도 갔다 온 놈이 석 달은 껌이지.
subtitles.pronunciation: Gyeou seok dal-iya. Neo gundae inyeon-do gatda on nom-i seok dal-eun kkeom-iji.
subtitles.translation: It's only three months. You did two years in the military—three months is nothing.

grammar.example: 겨우 석 달 = only three months
석 달은 껌이지 = three months is easy

subtitles.culture: Comparing to military service (의무 복무) is common in Korea. All Korean men serve about 18-21 months, so 3 months seems short by comparison.

subtitles.original: 동계 훈련한다 생각하면 뭔 짓을 못 하냐? 소름끼치게 열심히 사랑을 해봐.
subtitles.pronunciation: Donggye hullyeon-handa saenggak-hamyeon mwon jiseul mot hanya? Soreum-kkichige yeolsimhi sarang-eul haebwa.
subtitles.translation: If you think of it like winter training, what can't you do? Love her creepily hard.

grammar.example: 동계 훈련한다 생각하면 = if you think of it as winter training

subtitles.culture: 동계 훈련 (winter training) is notoriously brutal in Korean military. The friend uses military metaphors to frame faking love as a mission.

subtitles.original: 너. 너 진짜 내가 그런 놈으로. 그런 속물로 보이냐?
subtitles.pronunciation: Neo. Neo jinjja naega geureon nom-euro. Geureon songmul-lo boinyа?
subtitles.translation: You. Do you really see me as that kind of guy? As that kind of snob?

grammar.example: 속물로 보이냐 = do I look like a snob?

subtitles.original: 뭔데?
subtitles.pronunciation: Mweonde?
subtitles.translation: What is it?

subtitles.original: 오늘 우리 결혼 기념일.
subtitles.pronunciation: Oneul uri gyeolhon ginyeom-il.
subtitles.translation: Today is our wedding anniversary.

subtitles.original: 그래서?
subtitles.pronunciation: Geuraeseo?
subtitles.translation: So?

subtitles.original: 재작년에 식당 예약하고 이벤트 준비했는데 유난 떨지 말라고 당신 엄청 화냈었잖아.
subtitles.pronunciation: Jaejaknyeon-e sikdang yeyak-hago ibenteu junbi-haenneunde yunan tteolji mallago dangsin eomcheong hwanaesseotjanah.
subtitles.translation: Two years ago I made restaurant reservations and prepared an event, but you got really mad telling me not to make a fuss.

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to make a fuss/be extra'
grammar.example: 유난 떨지 말라고 = told me not to make a fuss

subtitles.original: 작년에 아무것도 안 했더니 언제부터 그렇게 내 말 잘 들었냐고 죽으라면 죽을 거냐면서 또 화냈잖아.
subtitles.pronunciation: Jaknyeon-e amugeotdo an haetdeoni eonjebuteo geureoke nae mal jal deureotnyago jugeura-myeon jugeul geonyamyeonseo tto hwanaetjanah.
subtitles.translation: Last year when I did nothing, you got mad again asking since when I listened so well to you—would I die if you told me to?

grammar.explanation: Connector showing cause and unexpected result
grammar.example: 안 했더니 = when I didn't do it, then...

grammar.explanation: Rhetorical expression meaning 'would you do anything I say?'
grammar.example: 죽으라면 죽을 거냐 = would you die if told to?

subtitles.culture: This phrase reveals the impossible standards Hyun-woo faces—criticized both for doing something and for not doing something.

subtitles.original: 지금 나 일관성 없다고 따지러 온 거야?
subtitles.pronunciation: Jigeum na ilgwanseong eopdago ttajireo on geoya?
subtitles.translation: Did you come here to call me inconsistent?

grammar.example: 따지러 온 거야 = came to confront me

subtitles.original: 응 그럴 리가. 꽃 들고 따지러 오는 사람이 어딨어.
subtitles.pronunciation: Eung geureol riga. Kkot deulgo ttajireo oneun saram-i eodisseo.
subtitles.translation: Yeah right. Who comes to argue holding flowers?

grammar.explanation: Rhetorical question meaning 'where would there be'
grammar.example: 사람이 어딨어 = where would such a person be

subtitles.original: 그럼 우리 결혼이 그렇게 꽃 들고 와서 기념할 만큼 서로 좋은 날이었나?
subtitles.pronunciation: Geureom uri gyeolhon-i geureoke kkot deulgo waseo ginyeom-hal mankeum seoro joeun nar-ieossna?
subtitles.translation: Then was our marriage such a good day worth celebrating with flowers?

subtitles.original: 솔직히 늘 그랬다고 할 수는 없겠지.
subtitles.pronunciation: Soljihi neul geuraetdago hal su-neun eopgetji.
subtitles.translation: Honestly, I can't say it was always like that.

grammar.pattern: ~다고 할 수는 없다 (dago hal suneun eopda)
grammar.example: 그랬다고 할 수는 없겠지 = I can't say it was like that

subtitles.original: 그런데 오늘을 좋은 날로 만들 수는 있지 않을까?
subtitles.pronunciation: Geureonde oneul-eul joeun nal-lo mandeul su-neun itji aneulkka?
subtitles.translation: But couldn't we make today a good day?

grammar.example: 만들 수는 있지 않을까 = couldn't we make it?

subtitles.original: 축하해. 우리 결혼 기념일.
subtitles.pronunciation: Chukahae. Uri gyeolhon ginyeom-il.
subtitles.translation: Congratulations. Our wedding anniversary.
subtitles.culture: Despite everything, Hyun-woo chooses to celebrate their anniversary genuinely, showing his conflicted but ultimately caring nature.

subtitles.original: 여기 꽃병.
subtitles.pronunciation: Yeogi kkotbyeong.
subtitles.translation: Here, a vase.
